newsitem.title: JORDAN: British land speed record hopes flooded in desert.
newsitem.headline: British land speed record hopes flooded in desert.

text.p: Flash floods in Jordan's southern deserts may have washed away British dreams of breaking the world land speed record this year.

Members of the Thrust Supersonic team testing their 9.5 tonne jet-powered car on the mud-flats of al-Jafr, 125 miles (200 km) south of Amman, said on Wednesday it had to be rushed to shelter after heavy rain turned the desert into a lake.
"We had to beat a hasty retreat," said Andrew Noble, whose brother Richard is leading the assault on his own world record of 633.47 mph (1,019.44 kph).
Noble said the team still hoped their 10 mile (16 km) test track may have avoided the worst of the flooding.

But no test runs would be possible before next week and the team would have to revise their plans to make Thrust SSC, powered by twin jet engines from a Phantom warplane, the fastest machine in the world on four wheels.
"Any more runs we do here are likely to be development runs rather than record attempts," Noble told Reuters by telephone from al-Jafr.

The team had planned to reach 650 mph (1,040 kph) in Jordan this year in preparation for an even more ambitious target next year -- breaking the sound barrier (about 750 mph/1,200 kph) in the deserts of Nevada in the United States.
So far the car, designed to reach up to 850 mph (1,360 kph) has not gone beyond a sedate 300 mph (480 kph).
"There is a possibility of coming back to Jordan next spring," Noble said, adding that he had been scouting around for other sites in the kingdom which could meet the team's needs.

One possible strip, near the border with Iraq, turned out to be "an excellent surface" but at just five miles (eight km) long, it was far too short for the car to reach its top speeds and slow down again, even with parachute brakes.
Another 14 mile strip at al-Jafr would need weeks of clearing before it would be ready.
Noble said financial restraints meant the team could not stay in Jordan much more than another two weeks.
"We're sitting here, hoping the weather will dry things out for us," he said.
